task: Using server, username, and password details provided to you, connect to your assigned server using ssh.
Create a new user account as the username of your choice

In your home directory, create a new directory called “memories”. Inside of it, create a text file which describes your favorite memory. Set the file access to full permissions for all the system (777).
Create a shell script which does the following:

subtask.a: Makes a copy of your memories file, naming it “privatemems”
subtask.b: Sets permissions of the new file to 755
subtask.c: Appends to the file the current system time

subtask.a: You may do this either starting locally and pushing to an origin (online) location of your choice, or you may create it online first and clone it to your home directory

task: Using the language you are most comfortable with, create an HTTPS (you’ll need to generate a keypair) server application with the following interfaces (very basic html/JS copied from internet for testing is completely fine here. Just cite your sources):

tasks.i: POST request handler where a user may specify a value to be stored under a key
tasks.ii: POST request handler where a user may request the value for a key
tasks.iii: POST request handler where a user may request all the current contents of the key-value structure
tasks.iv: POST request handler where a user may delete a key-value pair
tasks.v: POST request handler where a user may clear then entire key-value structure

tasks.i: Request handler where a user may upload a file
tasks.ii: GET request handler where a user may request a list (text or html) of uploaded files
tasks.iii: GET request handler where a user may request a specific file for download

task: Make sure to regularly commit changes in your local repo while developing and push those changes to your online repository.
Once application is working, containerize it:

subtask.a: Install docker on your provided server
subtask.b: Create a Dockerfile using the ubuntu image (https://hub.docker.com/_/ubuntu)
subtask.c: Start and test that your server runs and is accessible from outside the container
subtask.d: Set your container to start if system reboots

task: Commit and push Dockerfile in your repository
Configure system’s firewall to only allow SSH and HTTPS connections
Get a free domain name for the host ( https://www.noip.com/ is an option)
Get a LetsEncrypt SSL certificate for your server so that it stops complaining about your unsigned certificate (requires a domain name)
